Mexicans are a nationality that consists of both Europeans and the precursor Aztec and similar civilizations that inhabited the land on which Mexico sits, and much of their population is mixed race between them. Consequently, there is certainly a large share of “native” genetics and ancestry within the Mexican population overall, just as there is a great deal of Spanish ancestry, but it is worth noting that the Mexicans are not “Native American” in any sense related to the United States. Something I feel obliged to mention is that there is often a political argument along the lines that Mexicans should be allowed to immigrate to the United States freely because they are in large part “Native American”. I know this wasn’t part of your question, so disregard it if it isn’t relevant, but if it is, please understand that Mexicans have no historical claim or relationship to the United States. The tribes that traditionally existed in the United States and those that existed in Mexico were never friends, they were bitter enemies, from wildly different cultural groups religiously, socially, and linguistically. Even in the time where Mexico briefly controlled the American Southwest (purely a remnant of the Spanish Empire with no historical or cultural connections to that land), their sparse and thinly populated settlements were under constant siege and attack by Native American forces, who actively sought to exterminate them. The United States actually had to protect their tiny population after conquering the southwest, and that population was wildly grateful to finally have the protection of a responsive and sympathetic government. That population never left the United States, but was never significant either.

Mexico Is Home to DNA That's a World Apart, Study Shows “genetic studies Mexico consistently shows a European admixture comparable to countries that report white populations of 52% - 77% (in the case of Chile and Costa Rica, who average 51% & 60% European admixture respectively, while studies in the general Mexican population have found European ancestry ranging from 56% going to 60%,64% and up to 78%…Mexico's northern regions have the greatest European population and admixture. In the northwest, the majority of the relatively small indigenous communities remain isolated from the rest of the population, and as for the northeast, the indigenous population was eliminated by early European settlers, becoming the region with the highest proportion of whites during the Spanish period. However, recent immigrants from southern Mexico have been changing, to some degree, its demographic trends” So it may depend on where they come from in Mexico. “In 2011 a large scale mitochondrial sequencing in Mexican Americans revealed 85 to 90% of mtDNA lineages of Native American origin, with the remainder having European (5-7%) or African ancestry (3-5%). Thus the observed frequency of Native American mtDNA in Mexican/Mexican Americans is higher than was expected on the basis of autosomal estimates of Native American admixture for these populations i.e. ~ 30-46%” Also male lineage is more likely to be European and female indigenous (i.e. the Spanish men were the dads). “studies suggests a tendency relating a higher European admixture with a higher socioeconomic status and a higher Amerindian ancestry with a lower socioeconomic status: a study made exclusively on low income Mestizos residing in Mexico City found the mean admixture to be 0.590, 0.348, and 0.062 for Amerindian, European and African respectively whereas the European admixture increased to an average of around 70% on mestizos belonging to a higher socioeconomical level.” So it also depends on economic status; the poorer immigrants are more likely to be indigenous. It is such a mess I doubt you can accurately identify the whole population at once.

If you mean that Mexicans have native american ancestry, the answer is yes. Roughly, 85–90% of Mexicans have native ancestry, anywhere from small to greater degrees. Other ancestries include African, Asian, Etc. When the Spanish conquered Mexico, the soldiers, having brought no women from from Spain, were more than willing to take native (mainly Aztec) women first as concubines, then as wives when they converted to Christianity. It was understandable, since both cultures had many common elements. Eventually, the two streams merged to form one river. One example is the Virgin of Guadalupe, which is an image of the Virgin Mary, with native features, such as brownish skin and brown eyes. The fact that the Virgin of Guadalupe appeared on Tepeyac hill, which had been dedicated to an Aztec goddess makes it even more evident. I always thought the very same thing had happened everywhere else in Latin America, until I visited Peru almost 20 years ago. The conquest of Peru was a brutal affair compared to the conquest of Mexico, and I couldn’t help noticing many details. For example, in a church outside Cuzco, there was a statue of the Apostle James, riding his horse into battle while trampling an Inca shaman. The original version of this statue in Spain has the Apostle James trampling a moor. Not a very subtle way of making a point, if you ask me. Not conciliatory at all.

Population density. The indigenous population in the Empires of today’s Mexico (Aztec and Mayan) was very large. Much much larger than the one in today’s Colombia. So there was the same blending, but many more indigenous by an order of magnitude. It is estimated that at the time of the conquest, Tenochtitlan (today’s Mexico City) alone had 300,000 people and was one of the largest cities in the world (and it still is today). All the cities around it were also very big, and you can see that by going to any of the many pyramid ruins (there’s hundreds of them all over central Mexico, with large plazas and central squares, full aqueducts and other “large population maintenance” facilities). The people’s origin story of Mexico City has the famous eagle foundation legend that we remember by the emblazon in the flag, but it also mentions that the Mexica, after looking for a place to settle and not finding one that was not taken, also tried to settle along the outskirts of the lake, and continuously got kicked out by cities that claimed the land as theirs (which gave them extra satisfaction when later they dominated those same cities from their capital built on water using Chinampas, but I digress). This suggests that the populations around the entire lakebed (all the cities surrounding Tenochtitlan) was also very high even 200 years earlier (high enough to continuously raise armies to kick out interloper settler groups, even strong ones like the Mexica). They were also urban and advanced to such an extent that the Spaniards kept the emperor as a figurehead and intermarried the Moctezuma royalty (which is a Spanish dukedom to this day), meaning these very large populations weren’t exterminated, but were converted then intermarried with. Simply not enough Spaniards existed to “dilute” the genetics of that many people, particularly as they had all of Latin America to conquer and settle.
